questions.text: Which of the following is a specific sign for Graves' disease?
questions.solution:
Ophthalmopathy is the specific sign of Graves’ disease. 

Glycosaminoglycan deposition, lymphoid infiltrates and fatty infiltration are responsible for ophthalmopathy and dermopathy.

Grave's disease is an autoimmune disorder due to the production of TSH-receptor stimulating immunoglobulins (TSI) thereby causing hyperthyroidism. 

It is characterized by the triad of:

  • Thyrotoxicosis
  • Infiltrative ophthalmopathy (exophthalmos)
  • Dermopathy (pretibial myxedema)

Ophthalmopathy can sometimes precede or follow thyrotoxicosis, accounting for some cases of euthyroid ophthalmopathy.

Related Pearl: Signs in Grave’s ophthalmopathy

Stellwag's sign Infrequent blinking
Gifford's sign Difficulty in eversion of the upper lid

questions.text: A patient with Graves' disease presents with the following finding. Which statement regarding this condition is false?

choices.text: Acropachy is strongly associated with this condition.
It occurs in more than 50% of patients with Graves' disease.
It occurs almost always in the presence of moderate or severe form of ophthalmopathy.
Skin changes can occur after trauma.

questions.solution:
The given scenario along with the image is suggestive of thyroid dermopathy. It occurs in <5% of patients with Graves’ disease. Thyroid dermopathy is almost always associated with ophthalmopathy.

Thyroid dermopathy is most frequently observed over the anterolateral parts of the lower leg. Hence, it is termed pretibial myxedema. Skin changes can occur at other sites, particularly after trauma. The typical lesion is a noninflamed, indurated plaque with a deep pink or purple color and orange peel-textured papules.

Thyroid acropachy refers to a form of clubbing rarely observed in Graves’ disease. It is strongly associated with thyroid dermopathy.

Thyroid dermopathy usually does not need any active treatment, but if necessary, treatment includes topical, high-potency glucocorticoid ointment under an occlusive dressing or octreotide can be useful in some cases.

questions.text: A patient from a hilly area was referred with a partial small bowel obstruction confirmed on CECT. Conservative management was tried for a week, but he continued to deteriorate and was taken up for emergency laparotomy. On post-operative day 7, he developed atrial fibrillation. Investigations revealed elevated free T3 and free T4 levels. What is the most probable cause?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of the Jod-Basedow phenomenon, likely due to the administration of an iodine-containing contrast agent during CECT.

This phenomenon is characterized by hyperthyroidism due to enhanced thyroid hormone production following the administration of contrast agents and other iodine-containing substances. This occurs in:

  • Patients with autonomous thyroid nodules
  • Patients with pre-existing subclinical hypothyroidism (endemic iodine deficiency in hilly areas)

Option B: Wolff-Chaikoff effect is characterized by the transient inhibition of thyroid iodide organification by excess iodine, thereby decreasing thyroid hormone synthesis.

Option C: Basedow disease is another name for Graves' disease.

Option D: Plummer disease is another name for toxic multinodular goitre.

questions.text: What is the most common symptom of thyrotoxicosis?
questions.solution:
Hyperactivity and irritability are considered as the most common symptoms of thyrotoxicosis.

The following table summarizes the symptoms and signs of thyrotoxicosis in descending order of frequency:

Symptoms Signs
  • Hyperactivity, irritability, dysphoria
  • Heat intolerance and sweating
  • Palpitations
  • Fatigue and weakness
  • Weight loss with increased appetite
  • Diarrhoea
  • Polyuria
  • Oligomenorrhea, loss of libido
  • Tachycardia, atrial fibrillation in the elderly
  • Tremor
  • Goitre
  • Warm, moist skin
  • Muscle weakness, proximal myopathy
  • Lid retraction or lag
  • Gynecomastia

Rarely, there can be an associated mid-systolic heart murmur called the Means-Lerman scratch. This is heard in the upper part of the sternum caused by the rubbing of the pericardium and the pleura, due to the hyperdynamic circulation.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not true about thyroid storm?

choices.text: Symptoms are vomiting, diarrhoea, jaundice and altered mentation
The mortality rate is 10% with treatment
High doses of propranolol decrease  T4 → T3  conversion

questions.solution:
The mortality rate of thyrotoxicosis crisis is almost 30% even with treatment. 

The usual causes for mortality are:

  • Cardiac failure
  • Arrhythmia 
  • Hyperthermia

Related Pearl: Thyroid storm / Thyrotoxic crisis:

It is an emergency caused by an acute exacerbation of hyperthyroidism. 

Precipitating factors:

  • When a thyrotoxic patient has been inadequately prepared for thyroidectomy
  • Abrupt cessation of antithyroid medications
  • Stress
    • Infection
    • Thyroid or non-thyroid surgery
    • Trauma in patients with untreated thyrotoxicosis
  • Acute iodine load
    • Amiodarone administration 
    • Exposure to iodinated contrast agents
    • Following RAI therapy

Clinical features:

  • Fever
  • Tachycardia
  • Altered mentation (delirium, psychosis, coma)
  • GI symptoms (nausea, vomiting, diarrhoea)
  • Atrial fibrillation and cardiac failure - most common causes of death

Treatment of thyroid storm:

Treatment modality Effect
IV Fluids, ice packs Rehydration and external cooling
Propylthiouracil
(DOC)

Reduces peripheral T4 to T3 conversion
Propranolol

Block adrenergic effects

Reduces peripheral T4 to T3 conversion
Corticosteroids

Inhibits the release of thyroid hormone from the gland

Reduces peripheral T4 to T3 conversion
Lugol’s iodine/ sodium ipodate Inhibits the release of thyroid hormone from the gland
Digoxin Controls the associated atrial fibrillation
Diuretics and administration of oxygen

To manage cardiac failure

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is not associated with amiodarone therapy?
questions.solution:
Silent thyroiditis is not associated with amiodarone therapy.

Amiodarone has the following effects on the thyroid gland:

  • Acute, transient suppression of thyroid function i.e., Wolff-Chaikoff effect
  • Hypothyroidism in patients susceptible to the inhibitory effects of a high iodine load
  • Thyrotoxicosis may be caused by Jod-Basedow phenomenon due to the iodine load, in the setting of multinodular goitre or incipient Graves’ disease. It can also be caused by a thyroiditis-like condition.

Painless thyroiditis, or silent thyroiditis, occurs in patients with underlying autoimmune thyroid disease and has a clinical course similar to that of subacute thyroiditis.

The condition can occur in up to 5% of women 3–6 months after pregnancy and is then termed postpartum thyroiditis.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about amiodarone-induced thyrotoxicosis is false?

choices.text: Type 2 AIT is associated with intrinsic abnormalities of the thyroid gland
Type 2 AIT is due to lysosomal destruction of thyroid gland.
Type 1 AIT is due to Jod-Basedow phenomenon.
Colour flow doppler shows increased vascularity in Type 1

questions.solution:
Type 1 AIT is associated with intrinsic abnormalities of the thyroid gland.

Amiodarone is structurally similar to thyroid hormones and contains 39% iodine by weight. Amiodarone-induced thyrotoxicosis (AIT) is the most common manifestation of the effects of amiodarone on the thyroid.

Type 1 AIT Type 2 AIT

An underlying disease is present.

E.g., Grave’s disease, Multinodular goitre etc

 No underlying disease
Due to the Jod-Basedow phenomenon Due to drug-induced lysosomal destruction of thyroid tissue 
Increased vascularity on colour doppler Decreased vascularity on colour doppler

Administration of amiodarone should be stopped if possible.

Near-total thyroidectomy rapidly decreases thyroid hormone levels and may be the most effective long-term clinical solution.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about non-toxic multinodular goitre?

choices.text: It is more commonly observed in women
It does not occur in iodine-deficient regions
Most patients with non-toxic MNG have hypothyroidism
Risk of malignancy is higher than in cases of solitary thyroid nodule

questions.solution:
Multinodular goitre (MNG) is more commonly observed in women. It is common in iodine-deficient regions.

Most patients are asymptomatic and euthyroid. Sudden pain may occur due to haemorrhage. TFTs should be performed in all patients to exclude thyrotoxicosis or hypothyroidism. 

The risk of malignancy due to MNG is similar to that due to solitary nodules. Hoarseness, reflecting the involvement of laryngeal nerves implicate malignancy.  

Most non-toxic MNGs can be managed conservatively. Levothyroxine if used, should be started at low doses and then increased gradually. Radioiodine therapy is implemented for large goitres as it decreases goitre size and can ablate regions of autonomy.

questions.text: What is the major difference between non-toxic and toxic multinodular goitre?
questions.solution:
The major difference between toxic and non-toxic multinodular goiter (MNG) is the presence of functional autonomy in toxic MNG.

The pathogenesis of toxic MNG appears to be similar to that of non-toxic MNG. In both types, many nodules are polyclonal whereas others are monoclonal and vary in their clonal origins. 

Most patients with non-toxic MNG are asymptomatic and euthyroid. However, patients with toxic MNG have subclinical or mild hyperthyroidism.

questions.text: What is the most common thyroid malignancy?
questions.solution:
Papillary carcinoma is the most common thyroid malignancy.

Prevalence of different types of thyroid malignancies:

Type of malignancy Occurence
Papillary 80-90%
Follicular 5-10%
Medullary <10%
Others 1-2%

Related Pearl: Thyroid Malignancy - Most Commons

  • Most common primary thyroid malignancy – Papillary carcinoma
  • Most common thyroid malignancy associated with radiation - Papillary carcinoma
  • Most common malignancy of thyroid associated with lymphatic spread – Papillary carcinoma
  • Most common thyroid malignancy associated with blood and bone metastasis – Follicular carcinoma
  • Most common thyroid malignancy in iodine sufficient areas – Papillary carcinoma
  • Most common thyroid malignancy in iodine deficient areas – Follicular carcinoma
  • Most common thyroid malignancy associated with Multi Nodular Goiter - Follicular carcinoma
  • Thyroid malignancy associated with amyloid - Medullary carcinoma
  • Thyroid malignancy associated with MEN 2 syndrome - Medullary carcinoma
  • Most aggressive thyroid malignancy with worst prognosis - Anaplastic carcinoma
  • Thyroid malignancy with best prognosis - Papillary carcinoma

questions.text: The following patients presented with thyroid nodules. Who has the least risk of developing thyroid carcinoma?

choices.text: A 55-year-old woman with no voice abnormalities and nodule size of 3 cms
A 65-year-old woman with vocal cord paralysis and hoarse voice and nodule size of 3.5 cms
A 60-year-old man without any voice abnormalities and nodule size of 2.5 cms
A 43-year-old woman with no voice abnormalities and nodule size of 4.5 cm

questions.solution:
Among the options, the female patient with age between 20 and 65 years and no voice abnormalities and nodule size < 4 cm has the least risk for development of thyroid carcinoma.

Risk factors for the development of thyroid carcinoma in patients with thyroid nodules include:

  • Age less than 20 or greater than 65 years
  • Male gender
  • Increased nodule size > 4 cm
  • Vocal cord paralysis and hoarse voice
  • New or enlarged neck mass
  • Family history of thyroid cancer, MEN2, or other syndromes associated with thyroid malignancy (e.g., Cowden’s syndrome, familial polyposis, Carney complex)
  • Nodule fixed to adjacent structures
  • Exposure to radiation in childhood or adolescence
  • Extrathyroidal extension
  • Lateral cervical lymphadenopathy

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not true about thyroid hormone resistance?

choices.text: Inherited as an autosomal recessive disorder
Characterized by elevated thyroid hormone levels and normal or elevated TSH
Classic forms are caused by mutations in TR-β gene

questions.solution:
Thyroid hormone resistance is an autosomal dominant disorder.

It is characterized by elevated thyroid hormone levels and inappropriately elevated or normal TSH levels. 

Classic forms of the disease are attributed to the mutation in TR-β gene. Patients with this condition are often asymptomatic, as hormone resistance is partial and compensated by the increase in thyroid hormone levels.

In most patients, no treatment is indicated.

questions.text: Patients with what condition present with normal thyroglobulin levels?
questions.solution:
Serum thyroglobulin levels are normal in patients with thyrotoxicosis factitia, as it is caused by the self-administration of thyroid hormone. Its level is elevated in all other types of thyrotoxicosis.

Thyroglobulin (Tg) levels are particularly increased in thyroiditis, implicating destruction of thyroid tissue and release of thyroglobulin.

The primary course of action for determining the thyroglobulin levels, however, is in the clinical follow-up of thyroid cancer patients.

Following total thyroidectomy and radiofrequency ablation, thyroglobulin levels become undetectable. In the absence of anti-Tg antibodies, measurable levels of Tg are indicative of incomplete ablation or recurrent cancer.

questions.text: A patient presented with fever and painful neck swelling. She gives a history of sore throat and cough one week ago. Lab investigations revealed elevated T3 and T4 levels and elevated ESR. Which of the following statements about this condition is false?

choices.text: Treatment of choice is supportive care and NSAIDs
Women are generally affected three times more often than men
Both thyrotoxic and hypothyroid phases can be observed

questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of De Quervain’s thyroiditis, and it is not autoimmune in origin. It is subacute granulomatous thyroiditis that occurs secondary to viral infections.

Many viruses such as mumps, influenza, coxsackie, adenoviruses, and echoviruses have been clinically implicated in this condition. Peak incidence is observed at 30-50 years and women are generally affected three times more often than men.

Clinically, it presents as a painfully enlarged thyroid and is sometimes accompanied by fever.

It has three distinct phases:

  • Thyrotoxic phase
  • Hypothyroid phase
  • Recovery phase

Treatment includes large doses of aspirin, NSAIDs, steroids and/or beta-blockers to relieve the observable clinical symptoms. Antithyroid drugs do not have any role. In case the hypothyroid phase is prolonged - levothyroxine can be used.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is not associated with hypothyroidism?
questions.solution:
Graves' disease is not associated with hypothyroidism.

questions.text: A 4-month-old baby presented with a history of constipation, lethargy, and has poor activities. Clinical examination reveals jaundice, hypotonia and there was no palpable goitre. Laboratory investigations revealed low T4 and elevated TSH levels. Which of the following is not true about this condition?

choices.text: Most common cause is inborn defects in the synthesis of thyroid hormone
The developmental abnormalities are more common in girls
High circulating T4 level is needed to normalize TSH

questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of congenital hypothyroidism. The most common cause of this condition is thyroid gland dysgenesis, seen in about 80-85% of cases of neonatal hypothyroidism.

In the remaining cases of neonatal hypothyroidism, it is due to inborn defects in thyroid hormone synthesis and rarely due to TSH receptor antibodies. These developmental abnormalities are twice as common in girls.

Clinical features include:

  • Prolonged jaundice
  • Umbilical hernia
  • Enlarged tongue
  • Hypotonia
  • Delayed bone maturation

Permanent neurological damage results if treatment is delayed.

T4 requirements are relatively high during the first year of life. A high circulating T4 level is needed to normalize TSH.

Early treatment with T4 results in normal IQ levels by preventing neurodevelopmental abnormalities.

questions.text: Patients with autoimmune hypothyroidism have a higher predisposition for all except:
questions.solution:
Autoimmune hypothyroidism is usually not associated with type II diabetes mellitus.

Genetic risk factors for autoimmune hypothyroidism has been documented with HLA-DR3, HLA-DR4, HLA-DR5. A weak association also exists with CTLA4 gene polymorphism.

This may explain the relationship between autoimmune hypothyroidism and type I diabetes mellitus, Addison's disease, pernicious anemia, and vitiligo.

Less commonly encountered clinical associations include:

  • Celiac disease
  • Dermatitis herpetiformis
  • Chronic active hepatitis
  • Rheumatoid arthritis
  • Myasthenia gravis
  • Systemic lupus erythematosus
  • Sjogren's syndrome.

Related Pearl: Antibodies seen in some autoimmune thyroid disorders

Antibody Disorder
TSH receptor-stimulating Immunoglobulins (TSI) Graves disease
Anti TPO & Anti Tg antibodies Chronic lymphocytic(Hashimoto) thyroiditis

TRBAb

(maternal transmission)

  • Anti TPO – Anti thyroperoxidase antibody
  • Anti Tg – Antithyroglobulin antibody
  • TRBAb – TSH receptor blocking antibodies

questions.text: Most common symptom seen in patients with hypothyroidism is?
questions.solution:
The most common symptom of hypothyroidism is tiredness and weakness.

Symptoms and signs in decreasing order of frequency are given below:

Symptoms

Signs

  • Dry skin
  • Cold intolerance
  • Hair loss
  • Difficulty concentrating and poor memory
  • Constipation
  • Weight gain with poor appetite
  • Dyspnea
  • Hoarse voice
  • Menorrhagia (later oligomenorrhea or amenorrhea)
  • Paresthesia
  • Impaired hearing

questions.text: An elderly patient presents to the ER with symptoms suggestive of myxedema coma. Which of the following is unlikely to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
Hyperthermia is least likely in this patient. Clinical manifestations of myxedema coma include decreased consciousness, seizures and hypothermia.

Myxedema coma is a serious condition with a mortality rate of 20-40%. The clinical outcomes are independent of the detected T4 and TSH levels.

Clinical features of myxedema crisis include:

  • Impaired cognition, ranging from confusion to somnolence to coma (myxedema coma)
  • Convulsions and abnormal CNS signs.
  • Profound hypothermia (can reach 23°C), hypoventilation, hyponatremia, hypoglycemia, hypoxemia, hypercapnia, and hypotension.
  • Rhabdomyolysis and acute kidney injury.

questions.text: A patient came to the hospital with complaints of lethargy, increased sleep, and weight gain. Investigations revealed low plasma TSH concentration.  However, on the ​administration of TRH, the TSH levels increased. Which of the following conditions is likely in this patient?

choices.text: Hyperthyroidism due to disease in the pituitary
Hypothyroidism due to disease in the pituitary
Hypothyroidism due to disease in the hypothalamus
Hyperthyroidism due to disease in the hypothalamus

questions.solution:
The presenting symptoms of lethargy, increased sleep, and weight gain are suggestive of hypothyroidism. An increase in TSH on administration of TRH confirms the lack of stimulus for TSH secretion from the hypothalamus. 

Although decreased TSH levels can be seen in hyperthyroidism, clinical features such as lethargy, increased sleep and weight gain are not. This pushes the diagnosis in favor of hypothyroidism. 

If the disease was in the pituitary, there would be no increase in TSH secretion on administration of TRH (Option B).

Normally, the thyrotropin releasing hormone (TRH) is released by the hypothalamus. It stimulates the pituitary gland to release the thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH), which in turn stimulates the thyroid gland to produce T3 and T4 hormones. 

Low TSH levels may be seen in the following cases:

Disease Pathogenesis Presentation
Hyperthyroidism Feedback inhibition of TSH release Symptoms of hyperthyroidism
Primary disease of the pituitary Decreased release of TSH, thereby causing a decreased release of thyroid hormones

Symptoms of hypothyroidism.

Administration of TRH does not elevate the TSH levels in this case since the pituitary gland is abnormal
Primary disease of the hypothalamus Decreased release of TRH leading to decreased TSH and hypothyroidism Administration of TRH causes elevation of TSH levels since the pituitary gland is normal.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman with a history of constipation, dry skin and menorrhagia presents to the ER with altered sensorium, non-pitting edema, hypothermia, bradycardia, and hypotension. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history is typical of a case of hypothyroidism and the diagnosis is myxedema coma, which is a serious complication of hypothyroidism.

Myxedema coma is a part of a larger clinical picture of myxedema crisis. Myxedema crisis refers to severe, life-threatening manifestations of hypothyroidism. It is often precipitated by the administration of sedatives, antidepressants, hypnotics, anaesthetics, or opioids.

Clinical features of myxedema crisis :

  • Impaired cognition, ranging from confusion to somnolence to coma (myxedema coma).
  • Convulsions and abnormal CNS signs.
  • Profound hypothermia (can reach 23°C), hypoventilation, hyponatremia, hypoglycemia, hypoxemia, hypercapnia, and hypotension.
  • Rhabdomyolysis and acute kidney injury
  • A high mortality rate 

Other options: 

Option A: Without a history of or focus of infection, septic shock is unlikely. 

Option B: Cardiogenic shock would present with symptoms of left heart failure i.e. pitting pedal edema, abdominal distension, prominence of neck veins, and dyspnea. 

Option D: Hypoglycemia usually presents with sweating, palpitations, and tachycardia
